text: for the New York Times and the
International Herald Tribune this is
Suzy Menkes
in Milan with Peter Dundas the creative
director of Emilio Pucci Pucci so always
been a barn with an aristocratic edge
and I wouldn't say that Peter Gunness
has thrown that away but his practice
open he's made the clothes seem friendly
and fun and he's having a great success
in rejuvenating the house of Pucci
you're a bit of a blonde bombshell here
at Pucci you've really brought a lot of
sex and sexuality and a lot of changed
the brand tell us about that well really
what I've been doing has been completely
an instinctual I never set out to do
that in it in the beginning I was a
little bit surprised when the ones that
people - kept describing what I did is
sexy I don't think about it as
particularly sex yeah I love the body I
love the female form and so I suppose I
see it as a little bit of my duty to
embellish it and make it there be as
attractive desirable as possible for me
there's always a lot of talk these days
about heritage the heritage of a brand
is there something about Florence that
has to be brought into Pucci is there
something to do with its history or the
background well I think it's important
for Pucci because I think that all the
initial prints were very very much
inspired by the Renaissance architecture
and when I first started working and my
first day I've arrived at the picture
Palazzo and I've never been there and I
saw this incredible setting so I tried
to use the idea even the idea of that of
this woman that has this past of this
woman that lives in this Palazzo didn't
mix a dream and so it's very very strong
in what I do
how do you make that modern because you
know the past is the past
how do you bring it into the future I
usually say that it's important to be
respectfully disrespectful and I think
with Pucci was very important to show a
new side in a fresh side to the Pucci
girl and not that wasn't so obvious
because I think a lot of people had a
lot of preconceived notions about what
they thought Pucci would look like what
they should have thought that she would
look like in the runway I think it's
important today as well with these
houses to take in a flavor of it but it
doesn't necessarily have to be literal
interpretation so I don't believe that's
right what is your process of working do
you always start with a pencil on a
piece of paper do you start with the
fabric what's it all about well I love
sketching that's one of my favorite
parts of my job sometimes as well it's
the first sketch that actually is the
first look that goes up the runway as
well you've talked a lot about the Pucci
girl what about the Pucci woman doesn't
she have an odor or more sensible side
always laughs just a party for her when
I use the word the terminology girl it's
because I think it was important to to
push the brand forward and and make it
feel young and make it feel fresh I
think the girl
one can be a girl at any age and I
certainly know I'm a kid in many ways or
so I'm told
so it's just an expression the poochy
girl of course is the peachy woman as
well
